main_text.sentence: Recently, a detailed kinetic analysis of eleven different protein phosphatases implicated three specific phosphatases as the most likely mediators of Erk2 dephosphorylation, including mitogen-activated protein kinase phosphatase 3 (MKP-3) and protein phosphatase 2A (PP2A) [45].
For example, ia2, a transmembrane receptor protein phosphatase [27], has the highest level of transcriptional change among these kinases and phosphatases.

Furthermore, the identification of a phosphatase in enhanced Tat-mediated transactivation [39] could point to a possible, finely tuned interplay and balance between kinases and phosphatases in Tat-mediated HIV-1 transcription.

A large number of potential phosphatases have been implicated in the regulation of Erk phosphorylation [44]; consequently, identifying a specific phosphatase that may be responsible for such an effect was beyond the scope of the present study.

Other kinases and phosphatases co-regulated by both TGFβ pathways are G-iα65A (G-ialpha65A), a G-protein coupled receptor protein involved in neuroblast cell division and cell size control [33,34], and CG 9236, a calcium-dependent protein serine/threonine phosphatase [27].

Sequences only distantly related to Rhilphs, Shelphs or any other PPP phosphatases were detected in several fungi (including a putative S. cerevisiae phosphatase reported previously [23]), in Trypanosomatidae, a tick Amblyomma, an ascidian Ciona, Chlamydomonas, pine and diatoms Fragilariopsis cylindrus and Phaeodactylum tricornutum.

Reactivity was visualized colorimetrically [56] with alkaline phosphatase-conjugated goat anti-IgG antibodies [57,58] and a one-solution phosphatase substrate (Kirkegaard and Perry, Gaithersburg, MD).

source_text.title: The specificity of extracellular signal-regulated kinase 2 dephosphorylation by protein phosphatases
